data.title: Tito Puente: Why a Google Doodle video is celebrating the Latin jazz musician
data.meta_description: As well as paying tribute to the Nuyorican music master, the doodle is marking National Hispanic Heritage Month in the USA
data.text:
Today’s Google Doodle is honouring US Hispanic Heritage Month with an animation of the prominent American “Nuyorican” musician and internationally-renowned entertainer, Tito Puente.

The doodle, which is illustrated by New York-based Puerto Rican artist Carlos Aponte, shows Puente drumming through various points in his life.

Who was Tito Peunte?

Born Ernest Anthony Puente Jr on 20 April, 1923, Tinto Puente was an American musician, songwriter and bandleader of Puerto Rican descent – best known for his dance-orientated mambo and Latin jazz pieces.

His parents were both from Puerto Rico and the family lived in New York City’s Spanish Harlem area. He lived in the city until he was drafted into the Navy in 1942 to serve in World War II. He was discharged after three years in order to study music at Juilliard School of Music, where he learned to conduct and orchestrate.

He grew to the height of his popularity in the 50s, when he helped bring Afro-Cuban and Carribean sounds to the masses in America. He played multiple instruments including piano, saxophone, vibraphone, and timbales – a type of twin drum often used in Latin music.

His compositions spanned an acclaimed 50-year career, which saw him compose famous songs like Oye Como Va and soundtracks to many films, such as The Mambo Kings and Calle 54. He also made some famous appearances on shows including the Simpsons and Sesame Street.

Tito died after suffering a massive heart attack following a show in Puerto Rico in 2001. He was flown to New York, where he passed away from surgery complications on June 1 2001, aged 77.

Tito Puento’s songs

Dance Mania, was probably Puente’s most famous album – but he was well-loved for hundreds of songs, including:

Ran kan kan

Mambo Gozon

Quimbara

Que te pedí

I Like it

Mambo Birdland

Ay Cariño

Oye como va

Niña Y Señora

Timbale Solo

Salsa Y Sabor

Para Los Rumberos

Mambo Beat

Mambo Gallego

Picadillo

Tito On Timbales

Oyo como va

El Rey del Timbal

Déjame Soñar

Hong Kong Mambo

El Cayuco

Take Five

Pachito Eché

Babarabatiri

La Guarachera

Hay que trabajar

Sabor Gitano

Abaniquito

Maria Cervantes

A Gozar Timbero

Lullaby of Birdland

What is US Hispanic Heritage Month?

Every year, the USA holds National Hispanic Heritage Month from September 15 to October 15 – celebrating the history, music and culture of its citizens whose family background originates from Spain, Mexico, the Latin Caribbean and Central and South America.

September 15 is significant because it is the anniversary of independence for Latin American countries Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua
